The aerial shots of nuns playing badminton at Sacre Ceour are amazing. Audrey Tautou is a gorgeous heroine, and her supporting actors all contribute something unique. Four and a half stars.

title: Pure pleasure.
review: I have watched thousands of movies and there is not a single one that even comes close to making me feel the way I do when I watch "Le Fabuleux Destin D'Amélie Poulain" . It's like munching on endorphins for a couple of hours. It is beautiful beyond description. Watch it.

title: One of my very favourites!
review: I know that it's popular to bash critically acclaimed films, but I have to say, after more than a year of ignoring this film both at the cinema and the video store, I finally caught it on TV. I was completely blown away! I absolutely adored it, though many of my friends don't enjoy it. They said it was a little too out there for them, but perhaps because I myself am a little "out there" it really spoke to me. I could absolutely relate to Amelie and I followed her journey avidly. All the odd little touches in this movie work together to make the film as a whole a brilliantly wonky film. Different people are given a hard time often in real life, and it seems different films are also often dismissed without being given a chance too. Just give it a peek, you'll be so glad you did!

title: Trusting the fantasy
review: Amelie is a movie that takes you to a place that you thought that didn't exists . Amelie shows us, or me, that life is so much more than what we do day to day. Amelie showed me that yourself has to be happy if you want to make other people happy. Amelie is searching for the right guy, just as normal people do every day and we think it's normal but in the movie I see it on a whole new way, a way that I haven't seen before. It showed me that deep, deep inside we know where to look but we never admit it. We say it's just another fantasy but her "fantasy" was the man she fell in love with before she met him face to face. There for I think that we are just to afraid to do anything about our fantasies and therefor many of us live in fear of something that we don't know what it is but in reality it's just in front of us the whole time.

title: A movie to view over and over again, and be happy.
review: Visit Paris, the Montmartre area. Climb up to the Basilique du Sacré Coeur - church of the holy heart - and find the tourist office at the square Place du Tertre. There an 'Amelie' walk is provided, leading you along a number of spots that you will recognize from the movie. You will discover a beautiful area not known by tourists. In the end have a creme brulee at her café Les Deux Moulins.

title: The finest
review:
The finest film I have ever seen.

The premise - a shy, quirky young woman engaging and random acts of kindness and falling in love with an equally bizarre young man - is executed to perfection. Wonderfully shot with a vibrant soundtrack, Amelie is technically brilliant. It's also clever, funny and deliciously warm.

Highly recommended to everyone and anyone.

title: The film to restore your faith in humanity
review:
Having read such good reviews about this film but being a little wary of subtitles, it took me a while before I actually plucked up the courage to rent out 'Amelie'. A non-French speaker, I was pleasantly suprised that after no more than 15 minutes, the subtitles were conquered and in no way marred my experience of this exquisite film. 'Amelie' engages many emotions in the viewer, sympathy, empathy, sadness, happiness, and strangely, towards the end, exhilerating joy. How can this be? It was almost as though 'Amelie' herself had gifted me the enjoyment of this film! A great film for both the jaded and the life loving with a plentiful feel good buzz. Few films today run the interactive gamut of emotions like this to still make you feel a unique and special person. Touching and inspiring. I could go on and on but I don't want to start sounding like a motivational speaker!

'Life is a perpetual piecing together of broken bits'- Evelyn Waugh

title: Rather advanced
review:
Not a movie I expect you Americans to understand, because there is, as I understand very little or no French ancestry in th US, and whichever huguenots went to the US were soon lost in the American dream. In SA we have a great French heritage and many families can be traced back a LONG way and a lot of French culture, anecdotes, proverbs, satire and heritage has survived.

Maybe that is one of the movies I enjoyed the most. I have never been to France, so I don't know how realistic the movie is, but then again, this is a movie about Utopian views and one shouldn't put the thought too far out of mind.

I thought the soundtrack was really very good too and I thought the director used it very effectively. I just wish I was more fluent in French because I caught a word and a phrase here and there, and it was much funnier than the subtitles.

I am definitely going to find some more French movies!!!

title: Keeps you smiling from start to finish.
review: Amelie is simply perfect. The parts when she looks and the screen and smile make you smile right back at her, even the parts when she cries make you smile from how cute she looks. Beautiful film, probably the best from 2001 onwards. 10/10

title: Funny and engaging up until the last second
review:
At the start of this movie I was almost sure director Jeunet would never be able to keep up this incredible mix between different storylines, characters, colours, old movieclips, newsreels,.... for the whole runtime. But Jeunet succeeds admirably in holding on to this fast-paced rhythm until the very end.

This is in stark contrast with many recent US movies (or others) which seem to run out of steam after about 2/3 of the total runtime. Not this one !

PS : If you hate this movie and think it is unfunny, dumb, gloomy or boring, go out and seek some treatment before it's too late.

title: When I first watched the film my mind turned into red&green too
review: "I like looking back at people in cinema while they're watching the movie...". What can I say about Amélie story as it's my preferred film ever, including all genres, all countries and costs of productions. I mean doesn't really matter how much money was necessary to get those realistic effects in Titanic, Water World or Matrix... Then we go to cinema and pay same prices for all films. I paid about 4 euros an evening in November of 2001 and didn't need any special effects. A friend of mine had told me about but never expected it could be such an impressing pot. Amélie Poulain only needed some daily objects and lots of imagination to build a real story perfectly narrated. Simply loved the sense of humor (the way Amélie's mum dies), photography, the mediation of narrator and original winks (as that man who appears from the culvert...). I think such an optimistic point of view on the movie is really interesting... "A fabled destiny for you also depends on you!!!" as sometimes we forget that. Of course that way of making descriptions of people is unique!!!!! So since then, SHE could consider MYSELF a person who likes discovering simple films (and surprising ones at same time) just a normal day with no big expectations. Life's red and green!!!!! Merci Amélie!!!!!!

title: Heartwarming and enchanting, but enlightening as well...
review:
It's easy to see why so many people like Amélie. The film is absolutely beautiful, and as has been noted time and again, it plays like a modern day fairy tale. It seems, though, that some people can't understand how it's made its place at #20 in the IMDb's top films list. So, rather than discuss the general merits of the film, as many have done, I'm going to try and address the reasons, in specific, it's reached this level of popularity.

One of the most common write-offs about Amélie is that this is a "romantic comedy," and romantic comedies must by their nature be inferior to other films. Granted, there is a lot of support for this mode of thought, particularly in the form of very cliché, fluffy romantic comedies, the type you see Meg Ryan in so much. They're fun and they're sweet, but ultimately forgettable. But Amélie does not fit this mold. It's about love, definitely, but it's not about the typical self-centered notions of finding that person who "completes" her. On the contrary, she really discovers love through doing good things for others, affecting their lives. She feels gratified for doing so, but for reasons she can't really understand, she's still left feeling empty. When she stumbles upon Nino, her actions are quite playful and curious, but even when she begins to realize he might be that "special someone", she refuses to act on her desires, because such self-serving acts are against her nature. The lovers' eventual union only occurs after her neighbors, those people whose lives she's touched, conspire to return her favors. Thus, in the end, everyone who's found love or made happy has done so thanks to the generosity of others.

One of the other major complaints is about the pacing of the film, particularly that it drags in its final act. This is understandable as it could've been packaged more neatly with a few cut scenes at the end, but I understand Jeunet's intentions and would rather keep the film as is than chop it up for salability. Amélie and Nino aren't delayed from getting together simply so that Dufayel can make his inspirational little speech via her VCR. No, Amélie is absolutely petrified about taking chances and especially doing so for herself, and with such an attitude, she would never find happiness. Jeunet really drives this point in with several repeated and failed attempts. Some people find it unnecessary and are inclined to say, "I get it already!" But for those who can most closely relate--who just find it so hard to work for their own benefit--the inclusions of these scenes really adds to the effect, and drives the points home that good deeds will eventually be reciprocated, and that you must be willing to make yourself happy.

There are so many reasons why I love this film and it'd be impossible to lift them all, but I beg you to give the film a chance. If you don't like it, I'm sorry and a bit saddened. There may just be a chance, though, you'll think like I that Amélie belongs higher on the list than #20.

title: Life is beautiful.
review:
Audrey Tautou is Amélie Poulain, a pretty young girl in Paris who's lonely and emotionally withdrawn. She works in a cafe and watches the world go by and sees how everyone else is lonely too.

One day she happens upon a small tin box hidden in the wall by the little boy who lived in the apartment many years ago. It contains toys, pictures, and other mementos of his youth. She wonders what it would be like if he were to see these things again, so she tracks him down and arranges for him to discover his tin box in a phone booth. He's overjoyed and shaken from his life's sadness, and it hits her - she can step into other people's lives in secret and make them happy.

So she sets out to help those around her. The lonely woman downstairs who misses her husband, the lovestruck man who hangs out at her cafe, the mousy girl working behind the counter, the frustrated artist downstairs, the man in the Metro who collects torn pictures people throw away.

My favorite is her father, who's given up on life since his wife died and who lives alone as a recluse for the most part. Amélie steals his garden gnome and gives it to a stewardess friend, who takes it around the world with her and mails him pictures of the gnome having a good time everywhere. It shakes him up and he decides to travel to all the places he's wanted to visit but never had the nerve to do alone.

But Amélie hasn't taken care of her own needs, her own loneliness. She's fallen for the young boy in the Metro who collects pictures, but she's afraid to approach him. Amélie gives him hints she's interested, but she can't break the barriers she's put up between herself and the outside world and doesn't allow herself to embrace him.

Finally, with a little help from the artist downstairs who's figured out it's Amélie who's secretly been behind all these "miracles," she rushes to the young man as he's seeking her out too and they fall in love and seemingly live happily ever after.

It's a love story about two lonely people finding each other, but it has a humorous slant to it. Amélie is an impish character with bright eyes and a cheerful smile who goes through life trying to find the best in everything. Her boyfriend is also a romantic as he searches for the clue to the mystery of the man in the photos he puts together.

The film is well done and has some interesting features in the cinematography that border on surreal. Pictures talking to people, cats with funny expressions, the lamp talking to the picture frame, people coming out of nowhere and making comments. It's sort of like what she imagines not what's really happening, and it adds to the delightful aura of this most excellent film.

Definitely one of the best films that's come out in awhile.

title: Fabuleux indeed!
review: Wonderful, magical and delicious in every detail.  From the very beginning, describing Amélie's conception, to the end showing her blossoming, this is a gem of a movie.  Taking the typical Jeunet fantasy/hyper-real slant on life, this film has a real unique gallic charm.  The cinematography is superb and the rich colours and detail help to flesh out Amélie's comic strip universe. Perhaps this is the antithesis of the dark world described in Delicatessen. And Paris has never looked so beautiful (even the Metro looks clean!) Superb.  Can only the French do cinema like this?

title: Look Past the Unattractive Box!
review:
Almost 50% of the voters gave Amelie a perfect score, about twice as many people who voted "9" for this film. I was one of the majority, but I want to give you some insight to help you find more to understand about Amelie.

I first heard of this movie after seeing a less- than- attractive cover in a DVD rental store. A woman said that she was hesitant to watch Amelie because of the pale look of her character on the box (in the movie, she's not pale in any scene). I decided to rent the DVD after reading enough positive reviews here.

From the opening scene to the movie's conclusion, Amelie drew me into its world. View this movie with an open mind and don't take it seriously. It's a very light- hearted film, even though wheels on the plot power forward by a tragic event.

Amelie is a well- written, acted, scripted, and produced movie. And as the credits rolled at the end, I wanted to see more of Amelie, who was a wonderful and genuine character, one you wished lived in your own neighborhood. And I also believe that both women and men would really enjoy this. Most guys would fall in love with Amelie's eyes, and more women would enjoy the sensitive style of creatively showing a woman's emotions. But I get the sense that a few women may not care for Amelie's character, honestly.

The original music (no lyrics) of composer Yann Tiersen will stay in your head, even if you can't get past the subtitles. Tiersen did a fabulous job of creating a score that suits every scene it's played in. The audio is rich and expansive, and can be enjoyed with even the most basic speakers.

"Amelie" makes me wish that I had learned French, and I envy anyone who understands the language for being able to understand the dialog without having to read a translation. It can be a little difficult to have to watch two things at once -- subtitles and a movie -- because early on, you'll feel like you're missing the movie everytime you have to read the translation. But trust me on this, "Amelie from Montmartre" is a movie that you'll enjoy watching again and again. It's a rare treat to find a movie that doesn't get "tired." And as you watch "Amelie" again, you'll enjoy more of the cinematography and the lush, saturated colorful scenes.

The DVD has many different options to dive into, which is a great thing since you'll probably fall in love with "Amelie." One thing I would like to address is a criticism of too much sexuality in the film. First, North American culture is very conservative compared to the French, who view sexuality as another thing to enjoy in life. U.S. filmmakers may not understand the sensitivity in which director Jean- Pierre Jeunet filmed the sexual scenes, which were not at all gratuitous. I found it odd that someone suggested there was too much sexuality when 15 couples were shown engaging (creatively framed) at around 1/2 second each. Amelie was torn by her desire for companionship and intimacy. Her fears are unnatural in such an open- minded country where sexuality is not considered perverse or dirty.

PS- For lovers of traditional blues, watch for a B&W clip on the television of an elderly one- legged man tap dancing midway through the movie. His name is "Peg Leg" Sam (Jackson), and there are two CDs of music that this late singer recorded, "Kickin' It" and "Early in the Morning." Well worth the search.

title: All the poetry of Paris and Montmartre (where I lived)
review: This movie embodies all the poetry of Montmartre, a romantic district downtown Paris (with Sacre-Coeur). The music unites and supports a movie by Jeunet, former pro of advertising who knows better than anyone else how to create a magic atmosphere. A must-see !

title: great but too cutesy wootsy
review: a little too cutesy wootsy.  but really a great movie.  i can't deny that. it's interesting.  it's got the Alley McBeal thing with the fantasy type stuff, but as good or probably better and interesting.  it's a non-stop movie full of lots of things happening.  you have to just sit back and let it happen i think.  it's also nice and stylish and has great colors.

title: 'Fabuleux' is right
review: This is a fabulous and heart felt movie with a great cast, script, location(s), and score. I fell in love with everything about Amelie as soon as I got the chance to see it. I would definitely recommend this to people who like to see good things happen to good people, especially if you had a bad day or something like that.

title: Viva la conscience d'Amelie!
review:
Amelie (Audrey Tautou)is a paralyzingly introverted Paris sweetheart with a very different outlook on life. In the wake of the tragedy surrounding the death of Princess Dianna, she goes about her life, asserting her own sense of morality. Some people she helps, others she punishes. But who will help Amelie get what she deserves???

Amelie caught my attention and held it for two hours. Light-hearted, fast-paced and fun, this movie features visual effects (such as transparent pocket), that help the story move, as well as narration and some interesting views of Amelie's sub-conscious, viewed as through the Television. This movie is funny and well done, and Tautou's presence and charm put it over the top. An excellent film.

title: what?
review: i've seen this movie probably 30 times and i love it, BUT what is with the seen when she's looking for bredoteou and the strange he/she is being all flirty and she's says not now? i can't even explain it well because i try not to look during that part because it makes no sense to me. please help, it's killing me. thanks.

title: creme brulee's all round!
review:
If you don't like this film, you don't really like movies that much in my opinion. It's a wonderful, beautifully shot dream of a film. To the people who can't understand why it's ranked so highly here, well it's a great movie, thats all that needs to be said. The cafe in the film is real and located in the Montmartre area of Paris. I stumbled across it and it gave me good memories of a lovely film. (yes I had to have creme brulee, although I waited a lot longer than Amelie to get one!) You miserable sods who don't like the film deserve Scooby Doo the movie!

10 out of 10

title: I didn't know what to expect: a beautiful, funny, memorable...
review:
Amélie is one of those rare movies you see where you're transported to another place, I found it extremely captivating. The story of a girl in Paris, struggling to find meaning in life. By performing anonymous good deeds for the people she feels could use a bit of cheer, Amélie finds that she is not another hopeless case in a world where she feels alone. Amélie's newfound hobby takes her to a level of existence that she had never felt before. While questioning her thoughts, Amélie finally finds love.

Audrey Tautou (Amélie Poulaine) does a wonderful job portraying this curious, oddly enough, normal character. With great performances by all cast members, an exquisite score, and spectacular photography, this movie creates a feeling that you're in France with this charming, young, and sexy girl. This movie is exceptionally well-done. There are many emotional and intellectual layers in Amélie, along with a very real sense of humor, and a charm that many American films lack. Give Amélie a try, watch it once and you may find yourself coming back again and again.

title: Just brilliant
review:
This movie gathers everything in it what makes a movie just brilliant. The story has an extreme power in it, it tells about a naiev Parisienne who explores her own world in her own way. She finds out that just helping peolpe can end her introvert thoughts and make way to her dreams.

The colour, the cinematographic aspects, music and even the actor talents are fabulous. Some secondary actors are not that good and also the voice-over had too much text, but these are minor to the rest of the movie.

Just buy it!

title: Fabuleux!!!
review:
This movie is actually the reason why I registered myself at IMDb. This way I want to let you know how great this movie is!

The DVD was lying around at our place for a while, but the cover wasn't really attracting me to have a look at it. But at a cloudy afternoon, with nothing to do, I decided to give it a go. And how misleading the boring cover was. This movie is a jewel!

I really can't believe some of the comments made here. Amelie is a very satisfying movie, where you will not find any dull moments. The sweetness of the main character is stunning and is the aspect that really makes this movie the one that it is.

Possibly the best movie I have seen!

"She will change your life" -As taken from the cover of the DVD.

title: A wonderful movie, beautifully filmed, brilliantly acted
review:
It's unfathomable to me that people really exist who DISLIKE this lovely movie! "Amelie" is easily one of the most uplifting, charming, and visually stunning movies of the past 10-20 years. Audrey Tautou couldn't be any more perfect in the title role. She brings a sweetness and naivete to the character that's hard to imagine anyone else pulling off with such finesse.

Other comments have mentioned that Amelie's meddling in other people's lives is immoral, wrong, etc. Well, I don't see it that way at all. Everything Amelie does is with GOODNESS as its motivation...even her somewhat questionable antics (such as her tinkering in Collignon's apartment). The "letter" incident others have mentioned was done to cause HAPPINESS--and closure--in a sad, lonely woman's life. How can that be bad?!

Bottom line: If you haven't seen this movie...do!! It's wonderful from start to finish. (Note to self: You haven't watched "Amelie" lately. Better pop that DVD back in and treat yourself to another dose of utter joy.)

title: Plays The Strings of Your Imagination
review:
This film has an immense subconcious power to it. We have a main character who is sweet, innocent, and completely naive about the world around her. That is so very easy to relate to because we've all been that person at one point in our lives.

What makes the immersion into the character powerful is the fact that she's an adult, in the world; most of us were only like that when we were children. So it's like we're watching her through the eyes of our own childhood.

And we know what we've become, and not all of us are happy with how we've turned out. But here is Amelie - making a difference in so many lives in just the smallest of ways. So many of us don't have the courage or the insight to do that.

We get to watch her flower into the kind of person we all hoped we'd be. And the fact that she's an adult tells us that there's always a chance to start changing the world, inspiring the unispired and giving hope to the hopeless, even if it seems insignificant to you.

It's like Sophia said in Vanilla Sky: "Every passing minute is another chance to turn it all around."

title: The Greatest Movie Ever Made?
review:
Possible Spoilers!!!!

Wow. What else can I say?

This is the ultimate movie experience. It has everything! Excellent direction, gorgeous cinematography, great story, a score that always suits the mood and as for Audrey Tautou...

This is without doubt the single greatest performance by an actress ever committed to celluloid. In the title role she not only plays Amelie Poulian, she embodies her.

The tagline, "She'll change your life" is true. After watching AMELIE you will feel compelled to help a blind man cross the road or more importantly, you'll feel sure that there is a love out there for you. This is REAL magic.

title: What a breath of fresh air!
review: In the Netherlands everything with the word french in it, usually means something half finished, but that by no means applies to this absolutely wonderful film. It is funny, without slapstick, it is sweet, without sickeningly so and it is romantic. What else do you want from a feel-good film? The way the voice-over is doing his voice-overing is brilliant and the love-scenes are beautiful. Definitely a film to watch time and time again.

title: this movie is original and delightful!
review: Amelie is such a loveable character!  Flawed and insecure, yet good-hearted, she is charming.  Audrey Tautou captures all the winning qualities of this character, and makes you really care about her interactions with the quirky people in her life.  The camerawork is original and cheerful, the narrations are hilarious, and the message of the movie is wonderful: the best thing you can do with your life is to be a ray of light and goodness to those around you, just like Amelie.

title: cute
review: Audrey Tautou is adorable as the loveable Amélie, a kind-hearted introvert whose lack of parental physical affection guides her life into a realm of imagination and self-induced melodrama.  Tired of her passionless world, she decides to do "good" for strangers.  With the positive outcome of her initial philantropic deed, she moves onto other friends and peers in need, and in so doing is able to free her own introvert nature, burst out of her fantasy bubble, and find passion for herself.  To sum up this film in a word, it would be "cute" - everything, ranging from the lead actress all the way down to the editing style, bursts off the screen in a shout of "cuteness."  Despite its happy go lucky nature, the story is balanced with realistic glimpses into characters' lives (ie; the tale of the man who likes to eat his chicken and the discovery of his "treasure box").  Furthermore, the story falls a tiny bit short with Ally Mcbeal type special effect silliness and certain points where the film just doesn't seem to advance. However these points can be overlooked as the overall zeal of the picture allows us to enjoy this fantastic tale and in turn learn a little about ourselves and our need to once in awhile break free from our own shells.

title: Another beautiful story from a great director!
review: I suppose to fully appreciate Amelie, one would first have to appreciate the work of Jean-Pierre Jeunet. Jeunet creates characters that are sweet, simple, and (of course) interesting. Amelie, as the full title suggests, takes place in France. But not quite the France you may know. The France in Amelie is borderline between surreal and real, making the story of Amelie much like a fairy-tale. The main character, Amelie, is struggling to find her place in a world in which she does not seem to fit in. She feels finally at peace with her life when she finally feels she has found her goal in life...changing people's lives for the better. I don't want to give too much away, but overall, Amelie is a uniquely sweet story, with a uniquely sweet soul; just like...well, Amelie.

title: beautiful
review: I really liked this movie. Feel-good flick with a great soundtrack. The filming was experimental, had some interesting angles and the use of special effects were neatly done and adds something extra special to the story. The acting is superb and I fell in love with Amelie. See the movie, listen to the soundtrack.

title: I love Amelie.
review: What a fantastic movie, I've seen this movie many times and it's just as god and funny every time. Audery Tautou's performances is amazing, she is perfect as Amelie, she really make this movie flying! The atmosphere is also fantastic. Well, I can say that everything is perfect in this movie, everything you have to see it, is just so fantastic that you almost wound believe it. A suburb 10 out of 10.

title: She was a girl who didn't play much with the other children
review: Amélie Poulain is a shy person, much like myself, we dream all the time and never expect a wake up call. Set in Europe at Lady Di's death.  Amélie is a waitress at the 2 moulin restaurant in Montmatre.  She has lived lived there for five years and for the first time discovers a rusty box behind one of her bathroom tiles. Amélie determines herself to find it's owner.  The man, who once owned the little box is so overwelmed with joy that it sets her off into be a do-gooder.  With a little bit of humor, mind games, and mystery, Amélie shows us that every dream can have a happy ending, no matter how long it takes. 9.5/10

title: Amelie indeed.
review:
LE FABULEUX DESTIN D'AMELIE POULAIN (or just AMELIE in America) is one good movie. It is about a French woman named Amelie (Audrey Tautou) who is trying to improve the lives of others around her, by matchmaking, playing tricks on her neighbors, befriending lonely people, and so on and so forth. While doing this, she also improves her own life in certain ways.

AMELIE is truly great. Audrey Tautou is simply wonderful and charming as the protagonist, and most of the secondary actors are good as well. There are many genuinely funny moments, such as the fish scene. Heh. And the film's atmosphere and directing is truly unique. AMELIE just has such an innocent and funny air about it, which is really refreshing. The French is great to listen to, as well. It definitely should've won Best Foreign Language Film at the Oscars last year. AMELIE gets a 9 out of 10 in my book.

title: Outstanding!
review: This movie, with out a doubt, made me laugh more than any movie I have seen! I love the plot. It's two completely absurd people who fall in love before ever meeting because they're both weirdos!!! It's SO great!!! But that's not all, Amelie decides she wants to do good in the world, make a difference, and she does in the most absurd and hilarious ways.

title: This movie has everything great about it
review:
I have this movie on dvd (bought it in Bali) but there was no English subtitles! (And trust me, you'd get VERY lost in this movie without them) So I finally went and rented it out. It was awesome. Great.

I am male, 14 yrs old.

The great things about this movie:

1) The strange things. Amelie Poulain had many tragic moments in her life, she grew up as a little girl with strange 'fetishes'. And the way the movie is made is also strange. It is based around her, and what she does, which somehow (don't ask why) kept me watching it...and loving it.

2) The filming is great. Every atmosphere in this movie, whether in or outside, makes you feel warm. Everything is colourful, including the people. I don't know much about the French, but this movie has given me a view on them.

3) The passion. One moment you are wondering 'what the hell..?' and the next, you're laughing, or are sad. This movie brings out every emotion.

4) The music. The music....is really genuine. It is mainly the accordian, but all the music fits in with the movie. Anyone here who has seen it, don't you agree the music at the start is great!? And at the beginning of the movie.... The best song in it is "Amelie theme" by Yann Tiersen- Buy it or download it, it is so definitely worth it....or the music at the dvd menu Y'j suis jamais allé ☺

It's one of those movies you just HAVE to see more than once. I can't believe some people really didn't like it! (I think most of Europe appreciated it) Maybe they didn't have the subtitles.....

I enjoy drama at school (I am currently rehearsing for the musical 'the mikado'. It should be great, and I think any boy my age could enjoy this 'work of art' movie.

Words aren't enough to describe this movie. Do you agree with what I've said? Can you back me up?

I also hope the Americans don't try to make a 'redo' of this movie, it was classically made French and is great 'cause it hasn't been 'touched'. I think many American movies these days are too 'typical' sort of movies, where there is always a problem, then a soloution, whereas this is fun all the way through. Let's just hope that we can expect more of this sort of movie.

What do you think?

Hayden.

title: Sweet film
review:
In one word: it's a sweet film.

It's beautiful, charming, romantic, feelgood and visually, absolutely stunning to look at. The film has a storybook feel to it - the voice-over narration; the rich colour palette. Every frame feels hand-painted and timeless. If you're into quirky characters and oddball romance you'll love this.

My only criticism is that there was WAY TOO MUCH voice-over narration, especially noticeable in the first half of the film. This was almost bothersome. I would've preferred to HEAR the characters on screen (do the narrating) instead of having everything described and explained by some (invisible) old guy I don't care about.

title: Yet another reason as to why I don't bother with Hollywood anymore
review:
WOW!!!!!!

Where do I start?

What a great movie!!

For those who 'fell asleep' and consider it one of the worst movies ever. What can I tell you? It's your opinion but I fail to see how one can not appreciate such a gem of a movie.

I'd like to know what you consider "excellent" film making, I really would.

The comments about movies from "socialist" movies is ridiculous at best. I guess The Matrix and Hulk are masterpieces in your bubble of a world.

Thank you Amelie!!!!!!!!!!

This ranks as one of my all time favs.

10/10

title: a magical journey into happiness...
review: a fell good movie.   Amelie is a trip into a childhood imagination and an adult perspective toward the world.  The simple hints and background characters of her imagination set in a reality of France makes the film for both adults and children without going into just one path alienating one from the other.  Ignoring the fact that it's in french and subtitled, I consider this a good family film and a film for anyone interested in foreign cinema.

title: In my all-time top 10
review: A delight!  To laugh (hard and often), chuckle, well-up with tears, and be provoked to think about self, relationship, and the cultural/family contexts that shape these...all in one film - well, there are others that have done that for me but not made my "all-time top 10".  If you haven't seen this, you are missing a major piece of work.  It is so authentically human in the quirkiest, creative way.  (Yes, I gave it a 10).  See it.  Don't wait.

title: made me laugh, made me cry
review: Amelie is a quirky romantic comedy.  It is refreshing to see those two words together.  One of my favorite things about this movie is how it manages to be bizarre, unique, and surreal but still deals with real life issues.  Issues that are so close to my heart, however, and I do not know if everyone can connect to the story.  I think this piece of literature exemplifies everything I've studied in my World Literature class and that is why it speaks to me.  First of all, it revolves around the "artist figure." Amelie is an artist, disconnected from society but wanting to impact it. That is why I identify with her so much, because she is a shy individual and she learns that she can't keep letting her chances for happiness pass her by.  It is great that she is helping those around her, but you can't truly help others until you help yourself.  That beautiful, heartfelt central message is what had me in tears.  Good literature (and movies) give you an outpouring of mixed emotions which leave you not quite knowing what to think (and gives you a lot to think about after its over). The technical aspects of the film are quite brilliant.  The script has believable dialogue.  All of the characters and interesting and well rounded (The glass man being my favorite).  Everything fits together in a perfect piece.  The cinematography is quite stunning.  Each camera pan and swoop is just breathtaking.  The colors add to the fantasy of the story.  All in all, from the performances, to the storyline, to the look of the movie is shear brilliance.

title: Most unusual, well worth seeing
review:
It is a real rarity for me these days to see a film that I find genuinely original or unusual. But this really is one such film. It is also charming, funny and spell-binding. Yes, some of the surrealism grates a little, but the film moves so gracefully through its paces that the rare jolting moment is soon forgotten.

Lots of memorable scenes and events - probably a film worth seeing more than once as there is so much going on, especially for those of us who need subtitles.

This really is a super film - well worth seeing.

title: Charming.
review:
A wonderful, fun, and charming movie. Lots of eye candy to amuse, and plenty to think about later.

If you're capable of thinking, that is. Do not bother with this movie if you think France is a "socialist" country. It's over your head. Try "Jeff Foxworthy" reruns.

Those who don't believe there's a "War on Christmas" will marvel. In a world in which it makes sense to play away from trouble, to mind one's own business--in which it's hard enough to make oneself happy, let alone others--Amelie makes it her business to bring happiness to others with small but meaningful gestures. How she does this will charm you while you watch; why, and what it means, will stay with you a bit longer.

title: One of the best movies ever!!!
review: I bought this movie on DVD, as I missed out on it in the cinema but heard that it was very good. I didn't really know anything about the storyline so I didn't know what to expect. I can just say that the whole movie was absolutely stunning. This movie can cheer you up, even when you're enormously depressed. Audrey Tatou (Amélie) performs really well and makes you smile with her childish cuteness. One of the best movies I have ever seen!!!

title: Very charming Parisian antics.
review:
I can see exactly how this film appeared as such a breath of fresh air to mainstream film-goers, riddled with the alternating crudity and blandness of American romantic-comedies, and the non-existence of a British template. Hopefully, the astounding success of this film will encourage people to look out for films from other countries.

It should be remarked that "Amelie" is quite an artificial sort of French film; it plays its French-ness and difference as a trump card. The Paris conveyed is a beautiful cinematic conjuring trick - not to say that the city isn't a fine place, but its joie de vivre here seems so exaggerated that it takes on the depth of a sculpted cartoon. Visually, this can do no other than beguile you; the essence of innocence and early summery romance are captured in this film. It is a picture fully geared towards an international audience, as well as a domestic one; offering sheer escapist bonhomie and archetypal gallic qualities. It has the mark of intellect and 'Art' in its wonderful composition, and in the cast of characters - the wise, comic old artist enraptured by his Renoir. Yet, mundanity is given a gleeful pinch of whimsy with the old garden gnome subplot and the photograph album's resolution.

The only really central character in this stylized tableaux is Amelie Poulain, played by Audrey Tautou. Tautou does carry it; investing this almost superhuman, slightly manic and melancholy pixie with a great deal of charm. Part attractively coy, part knowingly wry and mischievous, she's like a perfect confection, and we of course know she'll end up with some romance in her life. This is Paris, after all. This is dealt with well, as it comes to her almost despite herself; her nimble do-gooding proves her to be very much the ideal worthy person we ourselves aspire to be. The other actors largely give pictorially effective, comic cameos; as players in this feelgood procession of events; Audrey Tautou has to add some gravity and maintain the mood of levity. A difficult task well carried out by the actress; the moments that most move are when Amelie is too coy to take the romantic initiative - she does have things to learn, despite her general excellence as a person.

"Amelie" is a perfectly crafted and poised popular film; perhaps overly calculated. But, a definite spot of enjoyable old-style entertainment, that will go down well with pretty much everyone with a romantic soul. It's an idealistic view of French-ness that cannot fail to appeal in these Hollywood-homogenized times.

Rating:- ****/*****

title: You´ll love her
review: Amelie will save your day. You will simply love her and the personality she has. The music composed by Yann Tiersen is just fabulous and supports Amelie´s actions and thoughts perfectly! You have to see this one!

title: A just fabulous movie
review: One of my absolutly favourite movies. You just must see this movie. Audrey Tautou is an amazing actor and just blossom through the whole film. You consistently get surprises and the filming is just brilliant. This is definitely an opener for french movies.

title: Naïve, goodhearted, positive, surreal and harmonic.
review:
This is one of the best films I've ever seen. I have seen this film 6 times and it still gives me this wonderful, relaxed and beautiful feeling when I'm seeing it.

Every individual in this film has a unique personality and every actor in this film plays so convincingly that this surreal universe becomes very real.

The film might provoke your thoughts about life, you might want to break free from your current life and go explore the small wonders that are everywhere in our world.

title: What do you mean bad?
review: "Lets just hate it cause everyone else loved it so much?" This film is perfection, thats all I need to say. Audrey Tatou is gorgeous and a really good actress, the film made me feel great and in love with the world. What other film can do that?

title: MUST SEE
review: after reading just very positive things about this movie i figured it could only disappoint. turned out to be one hell of a movie ! usually i'm into thriller/horror but this movie sent me off to bed with a smile. made it in my top ten movie list. buy this piece of art !!!

title: The most beautiful movie I've ever seen...and I've seen plenty!
review: From the very first words uttered until the closing credits, all your senses are on a heightened level of utmost cinematic ecstasy. The direction by Jean-Pierre Jeunet is the perfect balance of sound and color. From the very start you are immersed in the world of Amelie, a girl who realizes that there is more to life than what you and me consider important. Through her unconventional selfless acts she manages to better the lives of those around her...but does she have the courage to follow her dreams and better her own life?

title: One of the best movies I have ever seen
review: I had seen this movie on the shelf of my local Blockbuster store and was hesitant to rent it at first but finally got up the nerve to watch it and was like all the simplicities and truths of life were revealed.  I do agree the sex was not needed, it makes this sweet story a little darker, but the music is heavenly and the art direction is astounding and as for the storyline pure genius.  I would recommend this to anyone who likes romance, and humor and as for the comments about Run Lola Run in the upper commentary.  I LOVED THAT MOVIE.  It wasn't as ostentatious as you think. I was flipping channels and came across it and could not take my eyes off of it.

title: Yet another comment. Perhaps it's more than a movie.
review:
In the movie Amelie herself melts into a puddle of water on the floor. I feel like that when the movie starts playing. It's the jewel of my DVD collection.

The way the movie introduces the characters is so much more intimate and frank than we're accustomed to. The detail is so well crafted that each time you see it you find new suprises.

It uses some special effects but as they were saying around it's release, their use in this movie makes special effects seem wasted on other movies.

Let's not forget the scene where we first meet the grown-up Amelie in the cafe. The camera work really brings out how stunning Audrey Tattou is.

I've heard some people say they've found it a little slow, but having seen it on the big screen I guess I get very little of a sense of that. Even those who have found it such still love it.

It doesn't matter what genre you prefer movies from, there'll be something in this movie to cheer you up I think.

I dunno.. The back of the DVD quotes something like 'quite simply perfect' and I can't imagine how a movie could be more so.

title: Brilliant
review:
Possibly too cute & quirky for some, and not the laugh out loud comedy I was originally expecting. Yet despite this, Amelie has become one of my all time favourite films, and I have to admit to not being a fan of this particular genre at all (romantic/comedy).

You simply must see this movie, beautiful visuals throughout.

title: a movie who's magic grabs and doesnt let go
review: I saw amelie as of a few days ago.  It has been a long time coming.  There has always been something that has stopped me from seeing it.  So I finally got a copy of it and as I watched it I became enthralled by the beauty, simplicity, and magic of the main character and the story itself.  You root for the character almost from the beginning of the story as you see her terrible childhood, and see her loneliness only increase with time.  And instead of thinking of herself she thinks of others in an attempt to fill the void in her life.  But it does not last for long and she begins to see that her life isnt all that she wants it to be. And her attraction to Nino is quite apparent.  And you see that he is very much like her. . . a dreamer.  Audrey Tautou is absolutely magnificent in her role.  She exudes this sort of kindness and thrill for life but with a loneliness keeping her life from being perfect.  And the rest of the movie is filled with characters seemingly pulled right off the street and into the movie. . . not shells of characters with no depth like in most movie.  This movie is definately a 10 and rightly deserves it.

title: European cinema at it's delightful best...
review: This light extremely pleasant movie is full of virtues.The European artistic approach is more than obvious in each scene where every single detail is planned, the colors are superb,the soundtrack by Tiersen excellent with some of the most memorable music accompanying a film you'll ever hear (i actually bought the soundtrack BEFORE seeing the film)and the acting is funny and convincingly "cute" in a way that only the french can achieve...The movie as a whole is a beautiful fairy tale executed in a witty manner by people who enjoy what they are doing with imagination and faith .And the end result is sheer cinematic magic to anybody who is ready to watch with an open heart and mind.A journey into the beauty of a young woman's "soul" and the dreamlike clarity of her world-view. It's as if Amelie sheds her light to everybody and everything surrounding her rendering them interesting to the viewer as part of her world.Nothing groundbreaking, or dramatic or really "important" happens in the film..But the plot can't be criticized.Nor the depth factor if we want to be fair...The movie is after all and in all it's immense artistic beauty a ( somewhat romantic)comedy .The dialog and narration are very witty as is the surprise ending.And as in other European movies artistic references are also present. The effort to understand the inner emotions of a girl in portrait by Renoir is an obvious example.Asking for more would probably be something similar to asking more salt in a cake... So is it perfect? Well to me in it's genre is as close to cinematic perfection as anyone ever reached.The replay value of the movie is also very high .You will go back to it from time to time.All in all a solid 10/10.Enjoy without reservations...

title: Strange yet sweet
review:
"Amelie" is one of those films whose theme more or less boils down to "Live Your Life!" It's kind of an amorphous sentiment (how exactly does one live anymore than they already are?), one which is very hard to pull off without feeling pretentious or overly sappy. Thankfully, "Amelie" pulls it off.

Part of the reason for this is Audrey Tautou. As the title character, a woman who was starved for emotion and companionship most of her life but who manages to retain a tenderness in spite of the fact, Tautou displays a mix of innocence and cleverness, shyness and daring, which makes the character work. Her Amelie is believable as a woman who wants to make other people happy but can't bring herself to connect with them directly. This leads her on a variety of amusing and surreally complex escapades, including leading a man on a wild goose chase to restore a cherished photo album to him, or serving comeuppance to a mean-spirited grocer by sneaking into his house and altering small but significant details in his furnishings.

The owner of the photo album is Nino, who ultimately becomes Amelie's love interest. The album itself contains not family photographs, but pictures strangers discard outside instant photo booths. The album is a prominent image in a film where isolation and voyeurism are the key motifs (the film is set shortly after the tragic death of Princess Diana, who in the realm of "life as a spectator sport" was one of the biggest games in town). The symbolism here is wonderfully nuanced but occasionally heavy-handed, as in the case of a recluse known as "The Glass Man" who functions as Amelie's concious. Other characters include a hypochondriac, a bitter customer at the cafe where Amelie works, and Amelie's father, all of whom fit into the overall theme of embracing life. Some figure it out, some don't--finding out which is which is a journey worth taking.

title: Emotional, weird and exciting!
review: I had heard only good things about the movie before, but nevertheless just never watched it. What a loss, because this is a really great movie, with quite some sense of humour. It's emotional, weird and exciting. I love French movies anyway. The actress Audrey Tautou is also very impressive.

title: as good as harold and maude or world according to garp
review:
when i saw this film, i was prepared not to like it, not knowing anything about it other than it was french and had gotten rave reviews. i was expecting a pretententious talky movie as in "like water for chocolate". boy was i surprised! my favorite movies have always been good sci-fi and offbeat character farces like sex, lies and videotape or benny and joon or the accidental tourist. this film was right up my alley, and it delivered a ton of knockout punches.

i agree that audrey touteau is an adorable lead character right off the bat. that of course isn't reason enough to like a film. what i liked is that the first 10 minutes of the film deliver rapidfire absurdity after hysterical absurdity that relentlessly refuses to let you stop laughing. after all of this hilarity, the film hits you with a whopper of a little touching moment. excuse the contradiction. i haven't seen the film in a week, but if i remember right, the end of the goldfish scene is where the movie changes gears. it's an abrupt transition, but it catches you off guard and suits the style of the movie perfectly.

yes it's an emotionally manipulative movie, but that's what it's supposed to be. it pulls this task off perfectly. after the opening sequence, the movie's absurdities become more subtle and less frequent, but that leaves room for the drama to unfold. throughout the film, one is hit with little surprise heartstring tugs and belly laughs. i couldn't stop laughing in the scene where amalie's imagination goes into overdrive trying to imagine what could have happened to her love interest. it goes back into the opening's fevered pace of nonstop howls.

the cinematography is remarkable. the director mixes camera tricks with occasional computer animation, but the animations aren't really at all noticeable and don't detract from the movie's abstract realism.

if you're expecting a slow paced movie with alot of talking and subtlety, then this movie might not be for you. if you are searching for an absurdist rollercoaster ride with eye popping visuals and strange characters, then this film is perfect! don't expect to see it in dubbed english. (that's a good thing) after you get the gist of the movie in one viewing, you can then go back and watch it with subtitles turned off to see the films gorgeous visuals. it's equally as beautiful to watch as the best eye candy movies and as entertaining as the best romantic comedies.

harold and maude, and world according to garp have always been two of my favorite "i laughed... i cried" movies, but amelie is at least their equal but i'm leaning, after seeing it only twice, towards thinking it's even better because of it's beautiful visuals and it's unabashed trips into the truly absurd. it's like an acid trip that turns into a vacation. good cinema is supposed to be an escape from reality, this film takes you there in high style. i can't wait to buy the dvd and watch it again.

title: Visual Perfection
review: The film from start to finish is extremely well scripted and the visuals/camera shots are perfect.  A love story told like never before. If you like films like this then check out Delicatessen and city of the LOst Children.  Like watching and being part of a fairy tale.

title: A Perfect Movie
review: A piece of art, a movie that has taken me to the strange feeling..(ohh right i thought also that).. I think this is a movie for the people that are lonely characters and thinking too much with scenarios...It is just perfect...

title: Great cinematography!
review:
LyCifer says that this film has been "done before". Well, tell me which film hasn't been "done before". Good cinema is not judged by originality, but on entertainment value and good cinematography.

If a film can inspire you, make you cry, make you laugh, make you think, and make you feel good after you watch it, then it has done well. All films should be approached in this way. All films provoke some of those responses... but Amelie provoked all those responses in me.

If you haven't seen this film, you have missed out on an odyssey of emotions and feeling. Watch it with friends. Watch it alone. Above all, watch it! You won't be disappointed... unless you watch the Polish dubbed version. You have been warned!

title: Charming, definitely not an Americian film!
review:
I rather enjoyed the movie, it was cute and it's humor and wit something more expected by Americians to be Brittish, not French... don't ask my why, but there was a distinct Brittish feel to the humor, perhaps it should be better to coin it as "Euro-humor" rather than Brittish or French. The dramatic flair and exaggeration is definitely something you would not see from an americian, which is what made this movie endearing to Intelects in the US. the movie is twisted, illogical and quite silly... of of which is something Americians love in Monty Python, Are you Being Served, Ab Fab and other popular "imports"

If you lack the wit to laugh at a good piece of utter nonsense, then you probably won't find it amusing... Me, I greatly enjoyed it!

title: Nothing less of fabolous. A visual feast. Imagination par excellence.
review: Very few movies in my book rise to this level. The characters are carefully crafted, the script is as imaginative as 10 Hollywood movies combined, and the camerawork is of the quality I've learned to love from Jean Pierre. Kudos to a wonderful piece of work. Don't miss.

title: The Best "Chick Flick" of All Time
review:
My Big Fat Greek Who Cares, Amelie is one of the best movies I have ever seen. It is the #1 "Chick Flick" for me and I pride myself on the "manly movies" that I watch, for the 24 year old that I am.

At first I was weary about watching this. I've heard good things, yes, but it was French and I've never been a fan of French movies. Well my wife was dieing to see it, so we rented it, watched it, returned it the next day, and bought it on DVD that same afternoon. Since then i think my wife has watched it at least 30 times, and I've been involved in at least half of those screenings.

First off, you'll notice as the film starts out, one of the wittiest narratives that i've seen. Plus with the use of color and unique angles, the vision of Amelie is stunning.

Then we get to Audrey Tautou, the delightful Amelie. If she isn't the cutest, yet sexiest female lead to been seen in the last few years, i don't know who is. Plus her talent is fantastic. I feel all of her feelings, we know what she's thinking with a facial expression or gesture. The amount of things that she is able to say, without saying a word, is one of the things that I will most admire about Audrey Tautou. She's an actress that i will see movies, just to see her.

The supporting cast is great and very fitting in their respective place. In the end though, the star is Amelie. A girl we can feel happy for, sad for, excited for, and be in love with ourselves.

see.this.movie

title: Painfully funny and heart-breakingly sweet
review:
Amelie Poutain finds her calling in life, cleverly arranging events so that the people around her find the missing pieces in their own lives. But Amelie can't bring herself to take the same steps to break free of her own unhappy solitude. Even as her plans for everyone else bear fruit (occasionally in unexpected ways), she struggles to overcome her paralyzing fears. But she would do well to consider that she has no monopoly on scheming for the benefit of others!

Even ignoring the French dialog and English subtitles, this is obviously not an American movie. Its quirky characters are often simultaneously boorish and charming. Its storyline jumps from whimsical to depressing to silly to wrenchingly sad, with occasional heartwarming flourishes. But this American viewer found it quite entertaining, even while he was squirming as he identified a bit too closely with the lonely heroine.

One of my favorite elements was how Amelie's overactive imagination finds expression in the course of her ordinary daily life. (It's similar to the trippiness of "Ally McBeal", but with less slapstick and more heart.) I was also amused when Amelie found herself watching an English video clip which was, of course, subtitled in French, and I momentarily lost track of what language I was actually following!

All in all, it's a wonderful movie, and well worth the accolades lauded upon it.

title: Beautiful!
review: AMELIE is one of those very rare movies that is able to tug on my heart strings without being completely cheesy.  It celebrates life, and those weird habits and indulgences we all have that sets us apart from everyone else.  It is wonderfully written, and has georgous cinematography that puts you into an almost surreal reality.  Not to mention Audrey  Tautou is the most beautiful and radiant woman on this earth.

title: A superb piece of film-making!
review:
Jeunet is a master! politics of giving a foreign film recognition in two consecutive years meant that he missed out on oscar glory which was cinematic blasphemy. The film tells the story of a women who sets out to improve other peoples lives. by far the most touching moment is the blindmans tour of Mont Matre. The plot evolves into Amelie's search for her own personal happiness.

If you like Off-beat cinema, you'll love this! . If you like Surreal cinema, you'll love this! . If you like Expressionist cinema, you'll love this! . If you like Feel-good cinema, you'll love this! .

The final aspect of this movie which is unfortunately rarely mentioned is the score. the music strongly evokes the Amelie's feelings and actions and Yann Tiersen wasn't even nominated for an Oscar! The academy really needs to get their act together. If you like this you should see Delicatessen. It is far more surreal and some may find the humour distasteful, but it is another great French movie.

title: Jeunet at his best!
review: I love French film.  I especially enjoy Jean-Pierre Jeunet's films.  Of all his films, this tops them all.  The way he and Audrey Tautou bring out Amélie's character is fascinating.  I was left in awe.  I only wish American movies could be so touching as so many European films are.

title: Very cute!
review: This is a very cute and lovable film that will brighten your day. The beginning is very clever and witty, and throughout the film there is a fun vibe that tickles you and keeps you intrigued. After a few minutes I stopped noticing the subtitles! 8/10

title: Probably the most perfect movie ever made
review:
As a fan of viewing movies "fresh", that is, with no idea of what happens in the movie, it is my belief that this review contains spoilers.

Every aspect of this movie reaches a level of perfection unmatched by any other film. There is no excess footage and no scenes that need to be taken out (like the "robot factory" scene in Star Wars Episode II). Even the casual movie-goer will notice the attention to detail, especially in the use of the colors green, red, and blue that visually gives the movie more of a feeling that it is a work of art rather than just another movie. The cinematography is so fantastic that some of the camera shots almost overshadow and distract from what is being filmed. As I have often seen, the literal translation of the title is not used. The box says 'Amelie', the subtitle says 'Amelie from Monmartre', and the actual translation is 'The Fabulous Destiny of Amelie Poulain'. Yes, this movie is a love story, and no, it is not normal. It is about a strange girl who loves helping others, but has trouble helping herself and how she is instantly drawn to a strange boy who works at a carnival and a porn shop and goes around Paris collecting torn up photographs. Everything about this movie seems familiar, but it isn't - everything is new and fresh. It is rare that I like a "popular" movie, so take it from me, this movie really is really good.

title: A joyful work of art...
review:
Director/Writer Jean-Pierre Jeunet is one the most inventive story tellers of our time. When I saw his movie The City of Lost Children, I thought he must have seen one of my crazier nightmares. City is visually dark and monochromatic to support a dark affect. But with Amelie, Jeunet has created a joyful work of art -- and that in itself is an amazing achievement: Angst is cheap; Joy is a real challenge.

Amelie successfully weaves a number of true stories and urban myths (e.g., recovered letters change lives when finally delivered years later, and lawn ornaments send travel photos back to bewildered owners) around the protagonist. The imaginative Amelie of Montmartre goes through life testing every event for her destiny (`if he dips his finger in the sugar, he understands me'), and thus life is magical.

Jeunet strives to control every aspect of the medium to create his intended effect: He uses animation, beautiful camera moves, and digitally saturated colors (compare to Baran -- 'the grayest love story ever told' -rw), as well as light-hearted, folk-like music to accentuate the fairy-tale aspects of the story.

Most reviewers declared Amelie the feel-good movie of 2001, but I actually cried at the end -- I mean, come on, the fantasy of 'true love' is... well... tragic, isn't it? Ahh well... put your rational brain on hold and remember how, as a child, you once thought magic was possible.

title: Second time around
review: When I saw this film for the first time I didn't really think it was that good but when I saw it again the other night I realized; this is a Masterpiece. The colorful setting is fantastic and the wonderful characters too. If you haven't seen it... DO!

title: what can carry a movie?
review:
before seeing amelie i would have thought that the first essential element would be a strong story or screenplay. apparently i was wrong.

amelie has a very simple story. a young parisian girl decides to go around helping others without seeking recognition, and is simultaneously able to overcome her fears and find love. this sounds like standard, trite romantic comedy fare. i used to think so. i was wrong.

the first thing this movie has going for it is an incredibly engaging performance from audrey tautou (who by the way i am now in love with). minus all the other fabulous things about the film, her performance alone makes this an enthralling movie.

the second very strong aspect of this film is the cinematography, for which it was nominated for an academy award and somehow (shame on the academy) lost to fellowship of the ring. the first scene of amelie skipping stones on the canal is one of the most incredible i have ever seen.

the third strong aspect of this film is the color. the green everywhere, with contrasting red peppered throughout, and all the other vibrant colors make this movie an absolute joy to watch.

all these things, combined with a great sense of humor and a truly (as sap py as it may sound) touching story, make amelie a fantastic movie that everyone should see. i cannot imagine anybody, save the most coldhearted individual, not enjoying this. 4/4

title: Wonderful
review:
I normally steer clear of foreign films with subtitles, but I found this hilarious. It is very funny, with great actors and a good storyline. I didn't really know what this film was about or anything, but I am very glad that i watched it. It is worth watching, ans very entertaining.

9/10.

title: One of those rare films that can fairly be called "enchanting"
review:
Let me start by saying all of the negative things that I have to say, just to get them out of the way. First, I agree with the last reviewer that there is perhaps a bit too much sex in the film. If they would strike about three scenes, this would be a movie that (like The Princess Bride) I could recommend to absolutely anyone, even my mother or my pastor, with total confidence. Only one of the sex-related scenes really adds humor and advances the story (a couple make love in a public restroom, causing things to bounce around outside, a replay of a scene from the equally marvelous Delicatessen, by the same director).

Secondly, the film really does rely too much on voice-over narration. Sometimes what the narrator is saying is obvious, sometimes it's just a quick way to move us on to the next scene. Sometimes, admittedly, it works very well. But in a film that does such a wonderful job of telling the story in a creative way (using talking photographs and a gesturing statue, for example), it seems to me that more could have been done to spare us the voice-over in may places. If I had wanted a book on tape I would've rented one!

Now that said, this really is a marvelous gem of a film. The quirky humor is at times laugh-out-loud funny, and the story keeps one guessing. Unlike the last reviewer, I was not bothered by the dangling story lines; it seemed to me that these were just vignettes designed to draw me in to the world of Amelie. It would have been very "Hollywood" to tie them all up in a neat package in the last ten minutes of the film.

Visually, too, the film is stunning. Everything one sees is carefully placed to be evocative and stylized. Most of the colors are washed-out, so that every once in a while a bright object will catch the eye at a strategic moment.

All of the minor characters are fun, well-scripted and used to good effect in advancing the story. But the character of Amelie really makes or breaks the film. If, like me and most others, you find her to be charming, beautiful, and sweet, you'll probably love the film. If she reminds you of someone who used to make fun of you in high school, it'll be a long two hours.

9/10

If you like Amelie, I would certainly recommend that you check out Delicatessen. It's much darker, and somewhat hard to find, but the humor is just as wild and the visuals even more striking.

title: Trés Bien!
review:
What a wonderful, delightful film!

It has been over a decade that I have been so excited about a foreign film as I have about this one. It's delightful, the story is fun and the lead actress is adorable to watch as she does good for those around her....and finally finds love, for herself! You'll cheer for her and those around her, and the film is sprinkled with wonderful points animation that ACTUALLY advance the story, not that they are just there for CGI sake.

Highly recommended, a wonderful "chick" film that is also great for "guys" too!

title: One of, if not, the best film i have seen
review:
It's hard for me to describe how much I love this film. Absolutely everything is perfect about it. It's set in my favourite city in the world and manages to make it look even more beautiful than it actually is. The cinematography is absolutely amazing. The most stunning shot i have ever seen in a film is the one where Amelie skims stones along the canal where the camera goes right over her head and the whole screen virtually explodes in a cascade of colour. The plot is a universally pleasing one. "Cute hippy girl tries to make the world a better place by making people happy, and in turn finds happiness herself" and what the hell is wrong with that?

The soundtrack by Yann Tiersen is beautiful and sad and is perfect background music for when you're chilling out and thinking about life. If everyone got over the fact that subtitles do not mean a film is bad just because they have to read (which is never a bad thing) they would discover a shocking brilliant film (and a stunningly beautiful lead actress).It's funny, it's sweet, it's weird, it's abstract, it's beautiful and ultimately it makes life worth living, if only for a little while.

title: Just enjoy
review:
Don't question...just enjoy...a highly original film! I enjoyed it so much! If you don't like it, that's ok, but, at least see it...give yourself the opportunity...and be open to the wonder. BTW, the cinematography is astounding!!

And if you loved LOTR, this probably isn't for you. :)

title: Mixed Emotions
review: Im going to go out on a limb here and make a bold hypothesis. If you saw this movie without listening to the reviews, you most likely loved it. But if you saw this movie after listening to all the hype, you probably didnt like it. Most of the reviews that praised this movie included the words suprised or unexpected or great. Most of the reviews that disliked this movie included the words hype or overhyped or dissapointed. Its sad that hype can ruin a movie so much. I had heard nothing of this movie when I saw it other than I remember when it was released, and I must say, its a great movie that deserves the number 18 spot. Tis a sad thing hype can do.

title: Excellent Film
review: I would recommend it to anyone! It's a great film. Funny, as well as thought provoking. I love the scenes with the father and the garden gnome!

title: Too much suspense hurts the action
review:
I expected pretty much from this film and despite the fact that I can't say I am displeased, I do have to say that I am a little disappointed.

Jeunet made a good impression through Alien 4, which was interesting despite being the fourth movie in the series. With Amelie he played and I can't say he did a bad job, but there are some things which I am not happy with.

SPOILER

The choice of the leading actress was one of the best things of the movie. She has a very expressive face and such is needed to portray a person who lives in her own universe. Isolated, solitary, without much human contact...she creates a unique, pleasant but unhappy character. I wondered what her desire to help people might mean. It is not something she does because she feels fulfilled by it. I guess she does it because she does not have anything else to do and because she hopes to meet her prince charming, as she actually does.

At first it was enchanting...her way to fix things and make justice. Then it became a little confusing. Amelie is a shy person, that is certain by the way she goes around with "her man". She is not sure what to do and this leads to an annoying part of the film. It's all slow and things turn in ways they shouldn't, so that the movie loses some of its charm. I think too much suspense hurts the action in this case. The movie isn't what I'd call a comedy. It's a movie with some funny scenes, but not a comedy. It's a drama and a romance movie. That's what it is.

The painting that the old man has, with the girl, is seen by Amelie as the representation of her own life, but she does not dare to say it out loud. The man does notice it though and he tries to do what Amelie had done to many: help her. The characters are quite interesting, each and every one of them, but I don't really have everything clear in my mind and I am not sure if it is worth discussing the characters more than I have done already. Of course, her loved one is quite similar to her, but it was obvious they fit since the first time we saw them in the same image. A little bit strange was the picture thing, with the "invisible man". I understood that the idea was something like this: a man who fears not to be forgotten takes his pictures but then throws them away...we find out though that it actually was a repairman and not such a complex person. Should I understand that things are sometimes more simple than they seem?

After the whole middle part of the movie drags us along in Amelie's game with her love, the end is a little bit unnatural. It comes in such a way that it leaves you(left me anyway) asking why so much unnecessary stuff? There were some nice computer made scenes in the movie, of which I can not complain. They didn't quite have any effect on me. T The beginning of the movie was quite shocking, as was the whole movie actually: I expected something different.

All things find an explanation in the movie, so there is not much more to discuss about. In my opinion things could've been better.

There's this funny thing I noticed...most of the newer films(last 3-4 years maximum) which are in the top 20 movies here, are definitely strange. Memento and Amelie confirm this.I can only say LoTR got lost somehow in this maze of movies which lie at the top of the viewer's preferences.

Amelie is an interesting movie, but it does have its negative aspects as I've said. I can't give it a nine, hardly an eight fifty. More like 8/10.

title: beautiful, moving film... unless you're coldhearted and 100% left brained
review: Some people don't seem to like this movie; however, it is beautifully directed and fully stimulates the mind.  If you didn't (or don't think you will) like this movie try watching it again (or for the first time) and consider what you are given.  Absorb the entire situation and ask yourself why the situations, dialogue, editing and (for gods sake!!) colors are the way they are.  Why is Amélie's room red?  What does that mean?  How does it reflect the part of her character that isn't plainly given?  If you love art, even if you kind of like art, and can understand that not every thing you see is what it is (symbolism does exist in movies!!) then you should enjoy this film.  Even if you aren't into art, and you just decide that the director and writer just randomly picked colors for scenes, you should still like this movie because it's happy.  There's nothing wrong with an artistic movie that is happy.  Also, if you are fluent in French or can understand even a little bit it helps (everything is subtitled don't worry) the reason being is that you get to hear the inflection, the ferocity, the joy, the sadness --everything!  Anyone can read dialogue, but when you get to hear and watch and just take in what these great actors and actresses are giving us it can really overwhelm you.  That's enough--bottom line WATCH IT, if you don't like it call me an idiot on here later but you'd better be ready to support your argument.

title: Wonderful characters in a wonderful movie
review: A fairy tale for adults? A fable? An off the wall comedy? A love story? All these and more! This is a wonderfully refreshing and original movie. Amelie is the girl every man has loved at some time in his life. She is surrounded by a wonderfully drawn cast of characters. There are clever, creative film effects that stay in perspective. The producers wisely didn't allow themselves to get carried away by gimmicks and effects as so many do. A bonus is the splendid photography in  and around Paris and especially of French railway stations and trains. Nor, despite the happy ending, does this fit into the standard Hollywood genre. It is European and French to the last frame. 2003 is young as I write this but I doubt I will see much else this year that will be as good!

title: A delightful treat
review:
Like Hallstrom's 'Chocolat', 'Amelie' is a wicked, beautiful indulgence. Every single shot is like an oil panting, bursting with colour and energy and mystery.

What more can be said about a film already heaped with so many accolades its busting at the seams? Rarely is a film so outstanding in so many aspects. The most immediate reward for the audience is the cinematography - bold, lush, fecund. It has been suggested out that the Paris portrayed in 'Amelie' does not exist, but those people are wrong. The Paris in 'Amelie' is a place lovingly crafted into existence by the director, the cinematographer, the composer, the editor, the actors. For a few brief moments, we are allowed to live in a fairy tale.

Jeunet uses the camera to emphasize emotion already on screen, not to create them. Like the opening of 'The Royal Tenenbaums', a narrator introduces us to the characters that will shape the film, and shape our heroine, Amelie. Amelie appears to take in the world with wide-eyed innocence, but the audience can see the mischievnous that lies beneath. She is instantly adorable.

So much of the film is remarkable because of the look. Yet, like any good film, the heart of the film is the story and the characters. It is here that the film becomes magical instead of merely excellent, a film that treads the line between whimsy and heartache, of hope and hopelessness, of toil and reward with remarkable aplomb. Jeunet is a magician, and 'Amelie' is the act that brings the house down.

title: So uplifting and sweet!
review: Amelie is a wonderful and just plain sweet movie!  I just love how Audrey Tatou's big brown eyes make her seem so innocent yet her thoughts and experiences are so oddball.
